graphicslib3D
Class QuarterPatchDialog

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Container
          java.awt.Window
              java.awt.Dialog
                  javax.swing.JDialog
                      graphicslib3D.QuarterPatchDialog
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.event.ActionListener, java.awt.event.AdjustmentListener, java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, java.util.EventListener, javax.accessibility.Accessible, javax.swing.RootPaneContainer, javax.swing.WindowConstants
public class QuarterPatchDialog
extends javax.swing.JDialog
implements java.awt.event.ActionListener, java.awt.event.AdjustmentListener

This class is an editor which provides a graphical interface for making changes to the properties of IQuarterPatch objects -- i.e., any object which implements the "IQuarterPatch" interface. Typically such objects represent "Quarter-Revolution Surface Patches; that is, a surface patch generated by sweeping a cubic Bezier curve 90 degress about the Y axis.

The editor allows the user to change the properties of the IQuarterPatch object, including the values of the control points defining the Bezier curve used to sweep out the quarter-revolution surface patch. The resulting (new) values are then passed back to the invoking routine (that is, any changes made by the user via the graphical interface cause the original quarter-surface values to be modified.) Note however that using the editor to change the control point values defining the Bezier curve does not automatically generate a new 16-point mesh defining the quarter-surface; it is the user's responsibility to detect that the curve has been changed and to generate a new 4x4 mesh for the quarter-revolution surface implied by the new curve.

To use this dialog a program should first construct an instance of the class, passing it a reference to the parent Frame (for example, a JFrame). By default QuarterPatchDialog instances are hidden (not visible). To invoke the editor to alter a quarter-surface patch the user then invokes show(IQuarterPatch); this causes the editor to display the surface of revolution implied by the current curve control point values and allows the user to modify the control point values.

The dialog is modal; the invoking code is blocked until the user clicks either "OK" or "CANCEL" on the dialog.

If the user clicks "OK", the current values shown in the dialog are copied back to the specified IQuarterPatch object (that is, the object values are updated; note however, as stated above that the editor does not automatically generate the implied surface of revolution). If the user clicks "CANCEL" then no changes are made to the specified IQuarterPatch object.

The show(IQuarterPatch) method returns true if the user pressed OK; false otherwise.

Note: When using the dialog to enter new coordinate values in text boxes from the keyboard, it is necessary to press the "enter" key to update the coordinate value.

Version:
1.5 02/23/06
Author:
Matt Gross. Modeled after a previous version by Monika Jankun-Kelly and Dr. John Clevenger

Constructor Detail

QuarterPatchDialog

public QuarterPatchDialog(java.awt.Frame mf)
Constructs a default instance of the QuarterPatchDialog editor, saving the specified Frame (for example, a JFrame) as the parent (owner) of the dialog. The editor is initially hidden; invoke show(IQuarterPatch) to make it visible and begin editing the specified surface patch object.

Method Detail

adjustmentValueChanged

public void adjustmentValueChanged(java.awt.event.AdjustmentEvent e)
Whenever a scrollbar is adjusted, the command is sent here for processing.

Specified by:
adjustmentValueChanged in interface java.awt.event.AdjustmentListener

show

public boolean show(IQuarterPatch sp)
Makes the dialog visible and initializes it with the values contained in the specified IQuarterPatch object. When visible, the dialog provides interactive operations allowing the user to modify the IQuarterPatch values. Returns true if the user closes the dialog by pressing "OK" (which also updates the specified patch); returns false if the user presses the "CANCEL" button.
